texts.definition: Gameplay which for one player does not have symmetry with the gameplay of another player or that of previous game instances.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay which for one player does not have symmetry with the gameplay of another player or that of previous game instances.</style>

Games offers actions and goals to players. When these actions and goals differ between different players the games provide the players with <style="CurrentLink">Asymmetric Gameplay</style>. This can also occur when a player can have very different types of actions and goals between game instances of the same game.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, provide <style="CurrentLink">Asymmetric Gameplay</style> through letting players create characters to control that each have different abilities and roles depending on choices such as profession and race.

The board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Vast:%20The%20Crystal%20Caverns">Vast: The Crystal Caverns</link></style> provides each player with very different goals and actions, one being that of a dragon, another being that of knight, and a third being that of the cave in which the others move about. Other board games providing players with very asymmetrical gameplay include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ogre">Ogre</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style>. Both let one player control significantly more units than the other and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style> puts time limits on one player but not on the other. A weaker example can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style> where the asymmetry consists of differences in types and numbers of "command cards" (and to a lesser degree units).

<style="CurrentLink">Asymmetric Gameplay</style> is typically used in a game design to provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>. It is typically designed as part of a game through a more specific pattern, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-goals">Asymmetric Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Information">Asymmetric Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-resource-distribution">Asymmetric Resource Distribution</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Roles">Asymmetric Roles</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style>.

Naturally, <style="CurrentLink">Asymmetric Gameplay</style> is in conflict with having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetry">Symmetry</link></style> on the same level in a game.

As stated above, <style="CurrentLink">Asymmetric Gameplay</style> creates <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>. It typically through this also provides <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> as long as not all types of gameplay are guaranteed to be exhausted within a game instance. It can also create <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>.
